title: How Jacqueline Woodson Captures Every Side of Brooklyn
text:
Three generations of a Brooklyn family come vividly to life in Jacqueline Woodson’s Red at the Bone, a novel that feels epic in scope even though it weighs in at under 200 pages. The book is told from the points of view of five family members present at the coming-of-age ceremony of a 16-year-old girl in a Park Slope, Brooklyn, brownstone in 2001. Red at the Bone takes readers through the turbulent history of how the family has arrived at this specific place in time.

Woodson is the acclaimed author of numerous books for children,...
description: The author of Red at the Bone discusses her minimalist approach and the similarities of writing for young audiences and for adults
